1074814098452463616.text: "We define a "flaky" test result as a test that exhibits both a passing and a failing result with the same code. ... Almost 16% of our tests have some level of flakiness associated with them!"https://testing.googleblog.com/2016/05/flaky-tests-at-google-and-how-we.html …

1095357694045810688.text:
Insightful paper:
"An Empirical Analysis of Flaky Tests", Luo et al, FSE'14, http://mir.cs.illinois.edu/~eloussi2/publications/fse14.pdf …
Flaky test: test that does not always produce the same result on the same exact code

1110195746878443520.text:
On speculative execution in build systems.

I've seen two systems now where in order to speed up builds, build steps are executed on more than one system. Which ever one finishes first updates a global cache, and the slower job is cancelled.

1109491795396825088.text: The best of them depend on components and subcomponents that have been largely abandoned by their creators.

1109491150535229441.text: The bigger systems are tangles that have accumulated dependencies willy nilly over time, to the point of near collapse. No one dares to change anything because the consequences are unpredictable.

1109490207961870336.text: Most of these systems have names for their component parts that only start to make sense if you already have a ton of context. That makes it hard even to talk about them to outsiders.

1109489351690465281.text: I am giving a talk about complex systems. The more I look at them to prepare the less I am confident that I understand them.

1109197386654588930.text: The "T" key on my MacBook Pro has become detached from the keyboard, wondering if I should scrap the whole machine or if it's fixable.

1108455522355855360.text:
Once you have built a graph, you can start to reason about it. "What are all of the things that depend on foo.h?" is a question you'd like to tackle directly and easily. 

ninja e.g. can do this for you: graph out the whole dependency tree.pic.twitter.com/BQmMNwIRmt

1108453247763779584.text: What if the thing that made the graph didn't have to execute it? Then you'd have something like cmake + make, or cmake + ninja, where the "graph building" and "graph executing" bits get separated.

1108451438185906176.text: It took me a bit to realize that `make` - which both draws the graph and executes it - might not be the only way to divide up the problem into parts.

1108451058303549440.text: Caching in this context is labeling the points or edges on the graph in such a way that the system can say "we've done this before" and skip forwards through the graph rather than repeating a previous iteration.

1108450525937307650.text: For example, any build system that computes dependencies is drawing a graph, and then resolving those dependencies (through compiles or whatever) is effectively executing that graph.

1108449448412229632.text: A lot of things become easier for me to understand - but alas, harder to draw - when expressed in terms of graphs and transformations of graphs.

Thinking about optimization in #cicd systems. 

Optimize for time - fast builds.
Optimize for expense - minimum cost infrastructure.
Optimize for complexity - avoid overly complicated things.

Porting to a new architecture stresses all of these. 1/

1108062984230850560.text: All the computers in the world that you might ever want to solve your problem, and total job completion time is bounded by the slowest of them. 5/5

1108061160434216961.text: Amdahl's Law strikes again, though! Even with 1000-way parallelism, "Serial stages (archiving, linking, and stripping) consume almost half the total job completion time." (fig 6) 4/pic.twitter.com/nYgno9jduN

1108060428695941122.text: The basic idea (if I'm not reducing it too small) is that an analysis step decomposes a makefile's build environment into "thunks" of computation, each fully described, and then each "thunk" is executed in parallel on a function-as-a-service infrastructure.  3/

make -j1000 (and other jobs) on functions-as-a-service infrastructure

1108050688200847361.text: For example, you might configure your pipeline so that proposed changes that don't pass a syntax or code style check don't ever make it to full testing. Cycles and turnaround time for static analysis can be very quick and cheap compared to full-system testing. #cicd

1108048775921180672.text: For rapid feedback on changes, you need to do some active management of build queues. One concept is a "gating test" - break apart your test suite so that you can reject some changes cheaply up front rather than go through an exhaustive test suite every time. #cicd

CI/CD system goals:

Rapid feedback on change requests
Reproducible builds
Faithful tests that reflect real world conditions
Risk management for dependencies
Time-efficient builds of complex systems
Cost-efficient build infrastructure
Manageable complexity

1105879723312365569.text: Graphs resist simple numerical reductionism. In particular, it's really hard to quantify the importance of things which are beyond your event horizon, either up (towards the user) or down (towards the machine). 1105876742919593985.text: Lots of processes that are well understood by people who think and work in lists and spreadsheets naturally emit numbers. You list A1, A2, ... A(max), and then compute some measurement of "importance" for each, and then measure progress. Increase the n, decrease the n. 2/

1105876136817504259.text:
I mostly think and work in graphs. Lots of relationships - A depends on B, which in turn is built with C, which is written in X. So if there's a sufficiently interesting bug or deficiency in X, it affects A.

It's fundamentally hard to reduce a complex graph into a number. 1/

IRC was described in RFC 1459 (1993), but it had been going for a few years before then. And BITNET machines were connected by RELAY as early as the mid-1980s. 

Surprise, IRC is still going. 

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1459 
http://web.inter.nl.net/users/fred/relay/relhis.html …

My personal regret is not having the means to get to the Hypertext 91 conference, which had the first public demo of the World Wide Web. As Paul Jones account here shows it's not like this all happened in a vacuum!

1105543405659131904.text:
There was full-text search at that time, notably WAIS from Thinking Machines. Brewster Kahle's search engine for the Connection Machine, ported to Unix, provided search over a bunch of modest-sized document collections.

https://archive.org/stream/07Kahle000236/07Kahle000236_djvu.txt …

1105542844276752385.text:
Gopher was a 1991 start from the U of Minnesota. There was enough content from Usenet News and universities and other places published there to make it very reasonable e.g. to have the Usenet Cookbook searchable on the Mac SE in your kitchen.

https://kottke.org/06/08/gopher-still-going …

1105542064303943685.text:
30 years ago, if you wanted to have mostly literate discussions on the net (mixed in with a fair bit of nonsense) there was Usenet News. Netnews worked as well it did because it requires widespread cooperation between sites to share code and costs.

https://www.ibiblio.org/pub/docs/about-the-net/Usenet/usenet.faq2 …

3/

1105541232091164672.text:
Anonymous FTP is how we distributed software 30 years ago.

Here's a list of FTP sites from that time. Note lots of servers, each with specialties, usually that reflected a community of interest. "Archie", a search engine for FTP, debuted in 1990.

http://www.ibiblio.org/pub/docs/services/ftp.list …
